pullRequest.body:
Algebraic normalization tactics (`ring`, `abel`, etc.) typically require a concept of "atom", with expressions which are t-defeq (for some transparency t) being identified.  However, the particular representative of this equivalence class which turns up in the final normalized expression is basically random.  (It often ends up being the "first", in some tree sense, occurrence of the equivalence class in the expression being normalized.)

This ends up being particularly unpredictable when multiple expressions are being normalized simultaneously, e.g. with `ring_nf` or `abel_nf`: it can occur that in different expressions, a different representative of the equivalence class is chosen.  For example, on current Mathlib,
```lean
example (x : ℤ) (R : ℤ → ℤ → Prop) : True := by
  let a := x
  have h : R (a + x) (x + a) := sorry
  ring_nf at h
```
the statement of `h` after the ring-normalization step is `h : R (a * 2) (x * 2)`.  Here `a` and `x` are reducibly defeq.  When normalizing `a + x`, the representative `a` was chosen for the equivalence class; when normalizing `x + a`, the representative `x` was chosen.

This PR implements a fix.  The `AtomM` monad (which is used for atom-tracking in `ring`, `abel`, etc.) has its `addAtom` function modified to report, not just the index of an atom, but also the stored form of the atom.  Then the code surrounding `addAtom` calls in the `ring`, `abel` and `module` tactics is modified to use the stored form of the atom, rather than the form actually encountered at that point in the expression.

---

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

### PR summary [9cd0c2b88e](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19119/commits/9cd0c2b88e9ce7322d77097e263d50f93e3c2da5)

Import changes exceeding 2%

| %      | File |
| -      | -    |
| +5.26% | `Mathlib.Util.AtomM` |

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Util.AtomM | 19 | 20 | +1 (+5.26%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Util.AtomM`|1|

</details>

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ AtomM.addAtomQ`
`++ myId`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
Zulip thread discussing this PR: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.2319119.20atom.20representatives.20for.20ring.20and.20abel
Thanks for these improvements!

One thing I was worried about but seems to be okay is compatibility with [`CanonM`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Lean/Meta/Canonicalizer.html#Lean.Meta.Canonicalizer.CanonM), but we could easily add a `CanonM.canon` call around `addAtom`, so that should be all good.

@eric-wieser, any further review comments?

One thing I was worried about but seems to be okay is compatibility with [`CanonM`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Lean/Meta/Canonicalizer.html#Lean.Meta.Canonicalizer.CanonM), but we could easily add a `CanonM.canon` call around `addAtom`, so that should be all good.

@eric-wieser, any further review comments?
Can you update this docstring too?
Is this not what instance reducibility is for?
I don't see the relevance, can you say more?
Sorry, I was confused about what was going on here. Indeed, instance reducibility doesn't help.
Can you add this as an `addAtomQ` wrapper around `addAtom`?

Maybe add a usage suggestion? Because it's not completely clear why the `Expr` is returned for someone who doesn't know about this PR.
```suggestion
/-- If an atomic expression has already been encountered, get the index and the stored form of the
atom (which will be defeq at the specified transparency, but not necessarily syntactically equal).
If the atomic expression has *not* already been encountered, store it in the list of atoms, and
return the new index (and the stored form of the atom, which will be itself).

In a normalizing tactic, the expression returned by `addAtom` should be considered the normal form.
-/
def AtomM.addAtom (e : Expr) : AtomM (Nat × Expr) := do
```

```suggestion
return the new index (and the stored form of the atom, which will be itself).

In a normalizing tactic, the expression returned by `addAtom` should be considered the normal form. -/
```

```suggestion
def AtomM.addAtomQ {u : Level} {α : Q(Type u)} (e : Q($α)) :
    AtomM (Nat × {e' : Q($α) // $e =Q $e'}) := do
  let (n, e') ← AtomM.addAtom e
  return (n, ⟨e, ⟨⟩⟩)
```
so that the caller gets the fact that they are defeq.
The extra return value from `addAtomQ` means that the change on this line isn't needed any more
Sorry, which change?/which line?

Ah, I forget when you comment on a single line on github, it highlights the two lines above as well:
```suggestion
      q(NF.atom_eq_eval $x')⟩
```
Here's an idea: after running `ring_nf`, do `rw [show myId = myOpaqueId from rfl]`, then you don't need the `attribute [-instance]`s and can use reducible equality

I took a guess at interpreting your suggestion here: I added
```lean
opaque myOpaqueId (a : ℤ) : ℤ := a
```
before the test and then adding `rw [show myId = myOpaqueId from rfl]` below the `ring_nf`.  This fails because, well, `myOpaqueId` is opaque.

I guess you meant something else.  Please push it.
Thanks, that's in the distribution of things I tried to mean :). I pushed a working version.

What's tricky about your proposed test is that now it depends on `rw`'s notion of equality, as well as `guard_target`'s.  And I don't find `rw`'s notion of equality particularly principled or well-documented: it's stricter than reducible defeq, but it's still not literal equality of expressions -- it's something like "reducible equality, together with the same head-symbol, after unfolding abbreviations".

Are you particularly concerned about the robustness of the original test?  I'm worried that the changed test is vulnerable to changes in `rw` down the line, and would prefer the original test (or both).

```lean
import Mathlib
variable (P : ℝ → Prop) (f : ℝ → ℝ) (x : ℝ) (Q : Prop)

-- `rw` FAILS
-- `(fun t ↦ P t) (f x)` and `P (f x)` reducibly defeq with different head
example (h : (fun t ↦ P t) (f x) = Q) : P (f x) := by rw [h]

-- `rw` WORKS
-- `P ((fun t ↦ f t) x)` and `P (f x)` reducibly defeq with same head
example (h : P ((fun t ↦ f t) x) = Q) : P (f x) := by rw [h]; sorry
```
@hrmacbeth, feel free to change this comment if you don't think it captures the intent well

pullRequest.title: fix: more stable choice of representative for atoms in `ring` and `abel`
